Award.AwardTitle: Calmodulin-based allosteric switches as a modular platform for peptide biosensors

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1158784
Neel S. Joshi

All biosensing platforms rest on two pillars ? specific biochemical recognition of a particular analyte and transduction of that recognition into a readily detectable signal. Most existing biosensing technologies utilize proteins that passively bind to their analytes, and therefore require wasteful washing steps, specialized reagents, and expensive instruments for detection. The PI proposes to develop a new class of engineered protein switches that can actively sense peptide-based analytes and directly produce an output signal only when the analyte is bound.

Intellectual Merit: Combining the actions of sensing and output signal generation into a single protein will result in protein switches that are suitable for use in portable biosensing devices that can be used in the field and by untrained individuals, significantly simplifying the quantification of peptide-based analytes in biological samples.

Broader Impacts: The technology developed in this proposal will serve as a foundation for the further development of devices capable of rapid detection of disease biomarkers in biological samples or pathogenic toxins from environmental sources. Funding for this project will support a team of undergraduate researchers to participate in a unique international research competition for biomolecular design (biomod.net) and also support an ongoing outreach program to promote interaction between local high school students from communities underrepresented in the sciences and researchers at the Wyss Institute for Biologically Inspired Engineering.

This Project is jointly funded by CBET program at Engineering and Molecular Biophysics in the Division of Molecular and Cellular Sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of this project was to engineer a new class of protein-based biosensors based on the fusion of two domains – calmodulin and an enzyme. Biosensors of this type would be engineered allosteric proteins that would respond to small molecule or protein-based stimuli and produce a readily detectable signal. We then intended to use directed evolution procedures in which thousands of variants of this protein were simultaneously screened in order identify variants with enhanced ability to sense different targets.

 

This project produced one publication that described the successful creation of a switch protein (BLACaM) wherein the calmodulin protein (CaM) was inserted into the middle of the beta-lactamase enzyme (BLA). CaM was chosen because of its ability to undergo large and predictable conformational changes in response to binding to small molecules and proteins. Thus, in the presence of calcium ions, the CaM domain of BLACaM adopted and “open” conformation and disrupted beta-lactamase folding by holding the two parts of the enzyme apart from one another, constituting an “off” state for the switch. When a binding target for CaM was introduced, the domain adopted a “closed” conformation that allowed the enzyme to fold properly and be active, constituting an “on” state for the switch.  

 

In a second phase of this project, the goal was to use directed evolution to expand the substrate specificity of this protein switch biosensor. We did this by creating a library of ~10^8 variants of the BLACaM switch using a combination of error-prone PCR and a version of site-directed mutagenesis. The variants in the library were then screened for their ability to be activated by binding to a target of interest. In this case the target was delta-toxin, a toxin secreted by several virulent strains of Staphylococcus aureus. Although the results from this phase of the project have not yet produced a publication-worthy evolved variant, we did demonstrate that it was possible to identify variants with marginally better binding to delta-toxin. Despite its long than anticipated timeline, this work is ongoing in the PI’s lab and we expect to identify more biosensors with different specificities variants with a redesign of the mutation and screening process.

 

In addition to the scientific accomplishments noted above, this project also contributed to the training and mentoring of several young researchers. The project provided partial support for a team of four undergraduates, who performed portions of the library screening and competed in the 2014 bioMOD competition, which is a premier international research experience for undergraduates. The team was mentored by a postdoc in the PI’s lab, who gained valuable leadership experience that will help her start her own independent research lab in the future. Two of the students on that team further advance the research goals beyond the scope of the competition, and it contributed to the honors thesis work of one of those students. The participants of the biOMOD program also helped to establish an on-campus club that will help organize and manage future teams that will compete in bioMOD and a similar competition called iGEM (International Genetically Engineered Machine). This will ensure that Harvard undergraduates have the institutional resources to continue their participation in these events for several years to come.
